intro: Tragacantha antilibani, commonly known as the Antiliban tragacanth, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Fabaceae family and is characterized by its erect, branching stems and trifoliate leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers that bloom in summer, followed by seed pods that contain several seeds. Its root system is known for producing a viscous gum, which has been historically used in traditional medicine and as a natural adhesive. Tragacantha antilibani is adapted to arid and rocky environments, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
